proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: PL025 Low Profile Photonics Mast (LPPM)

proc:Name.footnote: FY18 and Out Procurement production lead times decrease to 24 months.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: Photonics Mast Type Modification: SHIPALT
VA Class advanced Low Profile Imaging masts including Low Profile Photonics Mast (LPPM). Procures initial modernization assets as well as spare masts later in FYDP to maintain overall spares ratio for imaging masts as quantity of imaging equipped ships increases. Maintaining sufficient quantities of installed and spare low profile masts imaging is essential to meet PACFLT requirements for all deploying VA class submarines in the Pacific to be equipped with low profile imaging masts. Beginning in FY20, procurement of Task Oriented Tech Insertion Mast (TOTIM) will provide vastly increased capability, reduced maintenance costs and increased development flexibility for new mast sensors.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: ML007 ICADF
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: ICADF Type Modification: SHIPALT (ES SYSTEM COMMS DF)
Provides advanced low-band COMINT Direction Finding (DF) capability compatible with CLASSIC TROLL and AN/BLQ-10 SSN ES system. Replaces obsolete AN/BRD-7 below decks equipment with modern, open architecture system compliant with Maritime Cryptologic Architecture.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: ML008 ICADF MMM ANTENNA
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: MULTI FUNCTION MODULAR MAST Type Modification: SHIPALT
Synchronizes improved low-band direction finding SIGINT sensor with coordinated N77/CNSG CLASSIC TROLL procurement. Replaces obsolete AN/BRD-7 antenna equipment with modern, open-architecture system compliant with Maritime Cryptologic Architecture.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: ML015 AN/BLQ-10(V) SSN ES SYSTEM
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: AN/BLQ-10(V)2/3/4 Type Modification: SHIPALT
Provides fully integrated, covert, forward area radar signal intercept and ID capability for installation on LOS ANGELES, SEAWOLF and SSGN Class Submarines.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: ML018 VA CLASS ES MODERNIZATION PATRIOT
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: VA PATRIOT Type Modification: SHIPALT
Procures Electronic Warfare Support (ES) Modernization upgrade of PATRIOT Phase B RADAR range finder for incorporation into the VIRGINIA CLASS Photonics Mast.

VIRGINIA Tech Insertion unit costs reflect copper/fiber diploops and hull penetrators needed to field Low Profile Photonics Mast (LPPM) and the Task Oriented Tech Insertion Mast (TOTIM) on these modernization hulls as well as higher base unit cost of VIRGINIA Tech Insertions. VIRGINIA Initial ISIS Backfits also contain copper/fiber updates for those hulls. This line item aligns the periscope, imaging, and support equipment with the Submarine Warfare Federated Tactical System (SWFTS) interface with the Combat Control and Acoustic upgrades in budget line items 5420 and 2150.

FY21 increases because only TI20 systems are being procured. FY22 increases as procurement of the more expensive TI22 units begin. proc:NonOrganicInstallation.proc:ImplementationMethodName: AIT:: Installation Name: TI/APB (SWFTS)

proc:P3AModificationItemGroup.proc:Description:
TI Processor upgrade provides additional computing capability over previous TI baselines and replaces out of production systems for installation on LOS ANGELES, SSGN, SEAWOLF, and VIRGINIA Class submarines. Provides updates to the AN/BLQ-10 (V) configuration baseline which incorporates current Commercial off the Shelf (COTS) processing technology and software to account for obsolescence avoidance, and Reliability, Maintainability and Availability (RMA) and associated Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) and technical data. Hardware builds include supporting platform level Submarine Warfare Federated Tactical Systems (SWFTS) interfaces.
Capability and Technical Insertion for AN/BLQ-10(V) provide spiral improvements to the baseline system which are designed to counter against new and evolving threat emitters. This effort is the transition of the EW AN/BLQ-10 TI modernization process to synchronize with SWFTS TI/APB process and model.
TI-16 baseline represents a significant change and increase in capabilities to enable software processing of digital data provided by EW Next Generation Architecture (NGA) hardware. TI-16 introduces the EW Server system that centralizes in software many functions that were previously handled in older, less capable hardware systems. Vastly increases coordination and dissemination of data.
Due to proliferation of multiple, older TI configurations, TI-16 still required to procure significant hardware updates to baseline older systems prior to installing new capabilities.
TI-16 is a concurrent requirement for installing EW NGA hardware.

proc:NonOrganicInstallation.proc:ImplementationMethodName: AIT:: Installation Name: AN/BLQ-10B(V) NGA (TI-16/18) Backfit Kits

proc:P3AModificationItemGroup.proc:Description:
Procurement of AN/BLQ-10B(V) NRE and modernization kits for ES Modernization upgrades for all submarine platforms. The rapid proliferation of complex radar, communications and navigation equipment available to potential adversaries creates a need for sustained and significant improvements to submarine systems in order to maintain tactical ship safety and operational effectiveness. Commander Submarine Forces and the Submarine Tactical Requirements Group (STRG) raised EW primary mission area in FY12 to be the number one modernization requirement. In addition, each procurement aligns with hardware builds supporting platform level Submarine Warfare Federated Tactical Systems (SWFTS) interfaces.
FY18 AN/BLQ-10B(V) Next Generation Architecture (NGA)(TI-16/18) Backfit procurements reflect kits to be installed in conjunction with TI-16 and TI-18 modernization. AN/BLQ-10B(V)NGA (TI-16/18) Backfit procured jointly with NAVAIR and the US Army leveraging prior NAVAIR funded development and providing a common hardware set for synergistic software solutions to be developed and shared between all three programs.
FY19 procurement of the AN/BLQ-10B(V)NGA (TI-20) Backfit in conjunction with TI-20 modernization.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The DDG Modernization Program is required to upgrade the in-service Flight I, II, and IIA DDG-51 Class ships in order to keep them relevant and affordable components of the Navy's Sea Power 21 Plan. The DDG Modernization Program is composed of a series of improvements in both the Hull, Mechanical, and Electrical (HM&E) and Combat Systems (CS). The modernization installations are planned for each ship at approximately the midlife point for each hull. The quantity line represents the total DDG Modernization availabilities (HM&E and Combat Systems) started in each fiscal year. HM&E: 3-2-6-5-4-3-4 Combat System: 1-1-2-1-3-2-3. Large funding increase in FY 18 due to the increase in DDG Modernization installations from 2 in FY 17 to 6 in FY 18.
The HM&E modernization will be comprised of the technologies transitioned from SCN funded DDG 111/112 and those additional improvements required to support the expected service life of the DDG 51 Class. The upgrades will focus on technologies that reduce workload and Total Ownership Costs (TOC) for the remaining hull life of each ship.
The centerpiece of the CS modernization is the Aegis Weapon System (AWS) upgrade. This upgrade will consist of the introduction of displays, computing equipment and the computer program required to implement Aegis Open Architecture (AOA) and replacement of the existing SPY-1D Signal Processor (SIGPRO) with the Multi-Mission Signal Processor. Selected warfighting improvements will also be installed in conjunction with the combat systems upgrade. This modernization program will provide a core modernization of the infrastructure "foundation" of each ship including the core engineering plan, core computing plan, and Combat Information Center (CIC). This modernization program will also provide an infrastructure foundation that will function as a landing zone for future warfighting capabilities.
[P40A / DM002 - LAND BASED ENGINEERING SITES]: Funds will be used to upgrade shore facilities for HM&E alterations providing risk reduction testing and provide for Combat System and HM&E training products.
[P40A / DM013 - CONJUNCTIVE ALTERATION DEFINITION AND INTEGRATION]: Procures Conjunctive Alteration Definition and Integration that includes equipment procurement, non-recurring and recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40A / DMCA1 - DDG-51 MODERNIZATION PROGRAM CONGRESSIONAL ADD]: Description: DDG Modernization Congressional Add Procures AN/SQQ-89 A(V)15 with Multi-Function Towed Array (MFTA) and other equipment for DDG Modernization Program that consist of hardware, software, system engineering, integrated logistics support, system test & evaluation, training, data, installation assistance teams, spare and repair parts, and program management for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40A / DMCA3 - COMMUNICATIONS UPGRADE FOR DDG MOD CONGRESSIONAL ADD]: Description: Communications Upgrade for DDG Modernization Congressional Add Procures communications upgrades for DDG Modernization Program that consist of hardware, software, system engineering, integrated logistics support, system test & evaluation, training, data, installation assistance teams, spare and repair parts, and program management for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40A / DMCA4 - SMART VALVE AUTOMATIC FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEM]: Description: Congressional Add for Smart Valve system. The Smart Valve is the enabling technology behind the Automatic Fire Suppression System (AFSS), which provides the sensing capability to detect ruptures in the fire main piping system that occur during a damage event; the ability to isolate damaged sections of the piping system; and the embedded "intelligence" to reconfigure the system to maintain firefighting capability where it is most needed without any operator intervention for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40A / DM6IN - INSTALLATION]: Funds are for installation of DDG Modernization equipment in support of the Fleet Modernization Program.
[P40A / MRG Procurement]: The contractor will engineer, manufacture, test and deliver a fully operational DDG 51 Class Main Reduction Gear (MRG). The MRG combines the input of two LM2500 engines to convert the high speed, low torque output suitable to drive the propulsion shafting, and the related support systems and equipment.
[P40A / DDG MODERNIZATION ADDITIONAL SHIPSET FY17]: Procuring one DDG 51 Class combat system ship set in FY 2017 will enable modernization of an additional destroyer in FY 2019, increasing capacity to meet Combatant Command Ballistic Missile Defense(COCOM BMD)demand and provide Naval Integrated Fire Control - Counter Air (NIFC-CA) capabilities needed to counter advanced missiles and strike-fighter aircraft.
[P40AMOD / DM001 - DDG MODERNIZATION HME (DVSS)]: Digital Video Surveillance System (DVSS) is a network of video cameras which are integrated into the Machinery Control system. This system is primarily a watch-stander situational awareness tool which supplements the workload reduction benefits of the new MCS.
[P40AMOD / DM001 - DDG MODERNIZATION HME (WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS)]: Shipwide Interior Wireless Communication System (SIWCS) - provides point-to-point coverage throughout the internal spaces of the ship as well as topside, topside-to-interior, line of sight ship-to-ship & line of sight ship-to-shore communications capabilities.
[P40AMOD / DM006 - MULTI-MISSION SSA/CWI MICROWAVE TUBES]: Procures Multi-Mission Solid State Amplifier (SSA)/Continuous Wave Illumination (CWI) Microwave Tubes upgrades for DDG Modernization Program that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40AMOD / DM008 - MULTI-MISSION BMD CAPABILITY]: Procures Multi-Mission Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) Capability combat systems that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40AMOD / DM010 - FCS STAMO]: Procures Stabilized Master Oscillator (STAMO) combat systems that include equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P40AMOD / DM012 - CEC]: Procures Cooperative Engagement Capability (CEC) combat systems that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P3A / DM001 - DDG MODERNIZATION HME (GEDMS)]: Gigabit Ethernet Data Multiplexing System (GEDMS) replaces the obsolete copper machinery control LAN infrastructure with a new system based on the widely used Ethernet industry standard.
[P3A - 2 / DM001 - DDG MODERNIZATION HME (MCS/DCS)]: Machinery Control System (MCS) replaces the obsolete control consoles while also delivering enhanced capability to the fleet through improved situational awareness and reconfigurable user stations. The new consoles use Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS)-based computers which connect via Versa Modular Eurocard (VME)-chassis technology. The VME architecture is expected to be supportable for the remaining service life of the ship and will enable computer upgrades within the chassis thereby mitigating future obsolescence concerns.
[P3A - 5 / DM001 - DDG MODERNIZATION HME (IBNS)]: The Integrated Bridge & Navigation System (IBNS) replaces obsolete bridge consoles and introduces flexibility with how the pilot house is managed during navigation. The key benefit is the ability for operating with fewer watch-standers,reduced watch standard workloads, and improved safety of navigation.
[P3A - 6 / DM003 - MK 160 MOD 15 GWS]: Procures MK 160 Mod 15 Gun Weapon System (GWS) that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P3A - 7 / DM004 - AWS UPGRADE]: Procures equipment for the AWS Upgrades that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P3A - 8 / DM005 - MULTI-MISSION SIGPRO]: Procures Multi-Mission SIGPRO combat systems that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P3A - 10 / DM007 - SPY-1D TRANSMITTER UPGRADES]: Procures SPY-1D Transmitter Upgrades combat systems that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P3A - 12 / DM009 - VLS UPGRADES]: Procures Vertical Launch System (VLS) Modifications, Evolved Sea Sparrow Missile VLS Modifications, SM3 Operability Heating Ventilation Air Conditioning (HVAC) and VLS MODS for SM3 Block 3 combat systems that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.
[P3A - 14 / DM011 - AN/SQQ-89 A(V15)]: Procures improved AN/SQQ-89(V)15 with Multi-Functional Towed Array (MFTA) combat systems to replace the installed MIL-STD AN/SQQ-89(V) that includes equipment procurement, recurring engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) products for DDG 51 Class ships.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Digital Video Surveillance System (DVSS) is a network of video cameras which are integrated into the Machinery Control System. This system is primarily a watch-stander situational awareness tool which supplements the workload reduction benefits of the new MCS.
Engineering Services:
Production Support Services are phased over a three (3) year span starting two (2) years prior to installation on a per hull basis. It includes five (5) elements that are related to the production and delivery of a usable end-item: Production Engineering, Quality Assurance, Product Improvement, Acceptance Test and Evaluation, and Contractor Engineering and Technical Services (CETS). Due to the phasing of the requirement over a three year period, engineering services will fluctuate depending on the number of ships in each year.
Five (5) elements and approximate breakdown is as follows:
Production Engineering includes preparation, test and technical evaluation of engineering changes to correct deficiencies in the production items; production configuration control; review and evaluation of production design data and documentation; and logistic supportability efforts.
Quality Assurance includes the preparation of procedures and the conduct of inspections, examinations and test during production that are necessary to deliver an item of the required quality as specified by the terms of the contract.
Product Improvement includes improving reliability/maintainability/availability, and the correction of deficiencies exclusive of contractual specifications.
Acceptance Test and Evaluation of a production item includes preparation of test plans, testing, data analysis, and data evaluation.
Contractor Engineering and Technical Services (CETS) includes the furnishing of advice, instruction, and training by commercial or industrial companies.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Department decided that a number of survivability improvements needed to be incorporated into mission-essential ship and combat systems during their acquisition and modernization. Shipboard fires have emphasized the urgent need to upgrade features and design standards that contribute to survivability.
[P40A / HB003 - EMERGENCY ESCAPE BREATHING DEVICE (EEBD)]: Emergency Escape Breathing Device (EEBD) breathing apparatus for firefighters are reaching their service life of 15 years and must be replaced. EEBDs address a high priority CNO effort to replace expired breathing equipment aboard ships throughout the Fleet. The requirement for this capability has been validated by the experience of numerous shipboard casualties. EEBD replacement is required to ensure that ships will deploy with operational safety equipment on-board to allow for emergency escape from shipboard fires.
[P40A / HB830 - PRODUCTION ENGINEERING (PE)]: PE includes development of technical manuals, Planned Maintenance System (PMS), Provisioning Technical Documentation (PTD), Program Support Data (PSD) and Allowance Parts List (APLs); engineering to manage procurement and material; support of design reviews.
[P3A / HB002 - MAGAZINE SPRINKLING IMPROVEMENT]: Replaces the detection system designed in the 1960s which has performance deficiencies and is difficult to support and maintain. Replacement includes the Fire Detection and Actuation System (FDAS) and the Motor-Operated Pilot Valves (MOPV). When the FDAS detects a fire, the MOPV opens to provide the sprinkling for the magazine. The FDAS consists of heat detectors, smoke detectors for amphibious ships, and associated controls. MOPV is the same item procured under HB007 - SOPV Replacement. FDAS/MOPV provides increased fire performance and reduced unit and logistics costs.
[P3A - 2 / HB007 - SOPV REPLACEMENT]: The Solenoid Operated Pilot Valve (SOPV) provides a way for remote control of the Aqueous Film Forming Foam (AFFF) and Countermeasure Wash Down (CMWD) systems. Existing SOPVs are unreliable, costly to repair, and produce the longest downtime for the AFFF system. Top Management Attention/Top Management Initiative (TMA/TMI) and INSURV interest due to impact of this item on AFFF system operation. Replacement of the SOPV with the Motor Operated Pilot Valve (MOPV) is required to ensure these systems are operational for emergencies. MOPV has a 50 year service life and will provide a significant reduction in preventative maintenance and cost.
[P3A - 3 / HB008 - SCBA REPLACEMENT]: Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) is a compressed air breathing device compatible with a firefighter's protective wear and helmet, and other damage control equipment. The SCBA are reaching the end of their service life of 15 years and are being replaced with 30 year cylinders. SCBA replacement is required to ensure that ships will deploy with operational safety equipment on-board to provide breathable air while fighting shipboard fires.
[P3A - 4 / HB009 - FIREFIGHTER ACCESS]: Funds the Firefighter Extraction System (FES) and Ladder Safety System (LSS) installations. FES provides rescue lifting capability to remove injured or exhausted firefighters from the bottom of escape trunks. LSS provides firefighters fall protection while using escape trunks for vertical entry firefighting.

The switchboard program provides mission critical switching capability required to link shipboard combat equipment including weapons, launchers, sensors, computers and navigation equipment. In essence, switchboards serve as the central connection point for most elements of combat and weapon systems, interior communications, data transfer, and command and control systems. They are designed to accommodate either analog, digital interfaces, or a combination of both. In total, this budget item supports approximately 200 ships and 1,000 pieces of equipment throughout the acquisition life cycle.
Functions include: data routing; action cutout; test and operating mode selection (including casualty back-up modes); power monitoring and control; circuit protection; peripheral equipment isolation; and signal processing, frequency conversion amplification and switching. In summary, the primary purpose is to provide systems intra and interface compatibility.
Changes in other elements of the combat and Interior Communication (IC) systems will frequently mandate either conjunctive modification to switchboards via ship change documents (SCDs), ordnance alteration (ORDALT)/ field changes (FCs) or partial or complete replacement of existing switchboards. Typical switchboard mods include hardware/field change kits, ORDALT/SCD/FC instructions, technical manual updates and revisions to other supporting documentation. Hull unique switchboard configurations require hull unique documentation. Subsequent alterations to these switchboards require hull unique design, hardware, installation, and checkout procedures. New Switchboards are normally installed during a regular overhaul by a shipyard.
Command and control switchboards are currently installed on and are required for almost all surface combatants and amphibious warfare ships. Individual switchboard unit cost varies from ship to ship, depending upon size, complexity, and whether analog or digital interfaces or some combination thereof are utilized. Modifications to existing switchboards via Ship Alterations (SHIPALTs), SCDs, ORDALTs or FCs are quantified by kits or change packages rather than individual units. The number of kits required for different classes of ships are as follows: DDGs/CGs require three to four (3 - 4) per ship, LSDs require two (2) per ship, LPDs require one (1) per ship, MCMs require (3) per ship and LHDs require two (2) per ship. The magnitude of modifications also varies, as Cruiser Modernization is considerably more complex than the Amphibious Class hulls. Switchboard hardware is normally procured by the Invitation For Bids (IFB) process, from manufacturers on Qualified Products List (QPL)-17000. There are currently six companies listed on QPL-17000. All contracts awarded are competitive, fixed price.
[P40A / GE003 ENG UPGRADES/MODS TO EQUIPMENT & TECH DOCUMENTATION]: Combat Systems & Interior Communication Switchboard Engineering and Modifications Upgrades to Equipment, Drawings, Technical Manuals (TMs) Allowance Parts Lists (APLs) and Allowance Equipage Lists (AELs). This line covers the costs to upgrade/modify existing equipment and associated technical documentation to implement and validate upgraded switching configurations essential for the ships' switchboards to properly integrate all elements of the Combat System and Interior Communication interfaces. The upgraded engineering modification drives the procurement of hardware modification kits (i.e., ORDALTs & Field Changes). These engineering modifications are essential to the functional deployment of Battle Force Interoperability.

This budget provides funding for targeted modernization of various HM&E systems on board Amphibious Assault Ships. Modernization efforts include the procurement and installation of: High Efficiency Small-Capacity (HES-C) Air Conditioning Compressors; various Interior Communications (IC) systems; automated Electric Plant controls and circuit breakers as part of the Power Management Platform (PMP); Brushless Generators for the PMP; main feed pump replacement; steam fire pump replacement; Shipboard Air Traffic Control Communications (SATCC); and Navigation Critical Data System (NCDS/NavCrit).
HES-C provides additional air conditioning capability to support growing electronic cooling requirements. IC Systems modernization provides up to date IC system installations necessary to maintain critical communications internal to the ships. Electric Plant controls and circuit breaker installation provides modern electric plant controls as part of the overall PMP to improve survivability and increase electric plant reliability. Brushless Generator replacement will reduce down time, total ownership costs, and maintenance costs associated with antiquated brush type generators. Main feed pump procurement and install replaces obsolete main feed pumps for the main propulsion boiler. Steam driven fire pumps are replaced with variable speed drive (VSD) electric fire pumps eliminating a substantial maintenance driver for the LHA/LHD Class Ships. Additionally, funding supports procurement and installation of SATCC and Navigation Critical Data Distribution (NavCrit) systems in support of capability requirements on Amphibious Assault Ships.
[P40A / Conjunctive HM&E Alterations]: LH002 Conjunctive HM&E Alterations includes design integration, equipment procurement, recurring equipment engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Services (ILS).
[P40A / Conjunctive HM&E Alterations]: LH002 Conjunctive HM&E Alterations includes design integration, equipment procurement, recurring equipment engineering, equipment integration and Integrated Logistics Services (ILS).

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - LHD Midlife, Brushless Generator for PMP

proc:Name.footnote: FY 2016 Brushless Generator installation was cancelled due to technical design problems discovered during the installation planning process. The ship set procured in FY 2015 is now planned to be installed in FY 2017. FY 2017 Brushless Generator install cost estimate increased due to a change in the rigging path driven by actual passageway and compartment dimensions captured during the ship check. Additional access cuts and interference removal are required. The ship set procured in FY 2016 will be installed in the next planned LHD availability, scheduled for FY 2022.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: LHD Midlife PMP
The Brushless Generator replacement will reduce down time, total ownership costs, and maintenance costs associated with antiquated brush type generators.
-Five (5) Generators are required to complete a shipset; The FY2015 procurement funding includes one shipset (5 generators) and one additional generator (1 generator) to be used for engineering testing (shock and vibration, etc). -The FY2016 procurement funding includes only one shipset (5 generators).

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - LHD Midlife HVAC IMPROVEMENTS (HESC)

proc:Name.footnote: FY 2016 and FY 2017 funds are required for significant engineering services for Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) improvements, which are required to resolve obsolescence issues in advance of the ship availability start in Q1 FY20. Funding In FY17 will be used to complete the HES-C Feasibility study, which will include NRE costs for the design of the chiller, production ROM costs, as well as start laying out the interface control document for the chiller that will be required by PY to install. In FY17 detailed design and production prototype manufacture will begin and anticipates put that unit through full first article testing.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: LHD Midlife HVAC
This ship alteration improves the Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) capability for the LHDs as part of the LHD midlife.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - Main Feed Pump
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: Replacement of obsolete main feed pump with new shock qualified unit to meet service life.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001- Navigation Critical Data Distribution (NavCrit)

proc:Name.footnote: NAVCRIT must be installed conjunctive with both SSDS MK II and CIC Room Rearrangement SCDs. Budget/funding must remain aligned across the FYDP.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: The Navigation Critical Distribution System (NCDS) procurements will be installed on LHD Class ships to replace and consolidate current analog Interior Communications (IC) data signals on the MK 70 and IC Switchboards, as well as analog indicators throughout the ships. The removal of the AN/USQ-82(V) Shipboard Data Multiplexer System (SDMS) will also be included. Network switches will be installed to provide data transmission from the NAVSSI Real Time Subsystem (RTS) to all clients and devices that require navigation data. Input Output Controllers (IOC) will be installed to convert the Navigation Sensor System Interface (NAVSSI) Standard Navigation Message from Ethernet to the required analog signal. Programmable Logic Controllers will be installed to handle all Navigation related alarms. Navigation Displays and Navigation Management Data Terminals (Alarm Panels) will be installed in various locations to provide the NAVCERT required data and alarms in the appropriate locations. A distributed IRIG-B timing architecture is also included, which includes IRIG-B clocks.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Control)

proc:Name.footnote: Must be installed concurrent with or after Power Management Platform (Brushless Generator). Switchboard Breaker Replacement and Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Controls) must be installed concurrently.

proc:Item.proc:Name: Power Management Platform (Electic Plant Controls) -- Procurement
Power Management Platform (Electic Plant Controls) -- Installation

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: Power Management Platform (PMP) modernization converts legacy controls to a digital automated control system. This system gathers and combines all Electric plant data so that it is available at any electric plant control station. PMP simplifies multiple step control sequences into single step operations and makes possible control capabilities that were previously too cumbersome for operators to perform. i.e. Baseload, and Real / Reactive power balancing. PMP implements a gradual Ship Service Turbine Generator (SSTG) turbine startup/shutdown sequence which allows the turbine to achieve stabilized temperatures more consistently, reducing stress on components and contributing to prolonged service life. System automation reduces electrical system transients and stress on breaker components by employing a Zero Power Transfer (ZPT) strategy, which limits the current flow through an individual breaker to zero during open/close evolutions. Switchboard Breaker Upgrade and Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Controls) must be installed concurrently. Collectively, these two non-severable modernization efforts provide enhanced electric plant (EP) situational awareness, reliability flexibility, and survivability through replacement of obsolete breakers with breakers currently used in other ship classes and through installation of modern electric plant controls and alarms. Brushless Generator Install must be accomplished prior to or concurrent with Switchboard Breaker Upgrade and Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Controls).

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - Switchboard Breaker Replacement

proc:Name.footnote: Must be installed concurrent with or after Power Management Platform (Brushless Generator). Switchboard Breaker Replacement and Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Controls) must be installed concurrently.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: Switchboard Breaker Replacement modernizes main switchboard breakers. Legacy circuit breakers currently utilized on LHD-1 class ships are obsolete, problematic and have a high cost of ownership. These breakers will be replaced with a unit that is also installed across multiple classes of surface ships. The replacement circuit breakers have a high reliability and low cost of ownership. All generator output, load center and bus tie breakers will be replaced as a part of this modernization. Switchboard Breaker Upgrade and Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Controls) must be installed concurrently. Collectively, these two non-severable modernizations provide enhanced electric plant (EP) situational awareness, reliability flexibility, and survivability through replacement of obsolete breakers with breakers currently used in other ship Classes and through installation of modern electric plant controls and alarms. SCD 11159 Brushless Generator Install must be accomplished prior to or concurrent with Switchboard Breaker Upgrade and Power Management Platform (Electric Plant Controls).

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - Oneway Announcing Systems Upgrade

proc:Name.footnote: IVN Modernization, Conference Bridge Modernization (on applicable ships), One Way Announcing System Modernization, and ICT Modernization must be installed concurrently.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: The One Way Announcing System modernization replaces the current obsolete 1/2/3/5/6/10 MC Announcing Systems with a Digital Integrated Announcing System (DIAS) controls and electronics. Installation of DIAS equipment resolves widespread obsolescence in order to restore announcing capability, and system operational availability, performance, and reliability necessary for support the ship's mission and secure crew safety.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - IVN System Upgrade

proc:Name.footnote: IVN Modernization, Conference Bridge Modernization (on applicable ships), One Way Announcing System Modernization, and ICT Modernization must be installed concurrently.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: Integrated Voice Network (IVN) system modernization replaces the existing Ships Service Telephone System (SSTS) aboard LHD 1 through LHD 4 with IVN. The legacy SSTS is obsolete and unsupported and contains single points of failure. IVN is a survivable telephony network providing Vital and Tactical internal communications capabilities. System architecture, end user, and interface configurations will provide commonality with the LHD 8 IVN.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - ICT Upgrade

proc:Name.footnote: IVN Modernization, Conference Bridge Modernization (on applicable ships), One Way Announcing System Modernization, and ICT Modernization must be installed concurrently.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: ICT modernization replaces the obsolete 7300-Series Programmable Integrated Communications Terminals (PICTs) with modern, supported Integrated Communication Terminals (ICT). ICT modernization will align LHD1 - 7 ICT configurations with LHD 8 through additions, deletions and/or one for one replacement to achieve United States Marine Corp (USMC) requirements.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - HYDRA Upgrade (LHD 1-3)
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: LHD 1 Class HYDRA modernization replaces the out of production P7100/MRK fixed and portable radios with XG-75 radios, replaces obsolete AN/SRC-55 (HYDRA) electronic components, adds vital wireless encrypted communications capability in below deck spaces, and incorporates the industry standard Association of Public Safety Communications Officials (APCO) P-25 signaling protocol. The HYDRA Wireless Communication System provides wireless communications capability supporting Flight Deck, Small Boat operations, Damage Control, and Security efforts. HYDRA modernization will create commonality with equipment installed in the LSD 41/49 class, CG-47 class, and CVN-68 class, as well as new construction including LHA-7, LPD-28, CVN-79 and follow-on hulls.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: LH001 - HYDRA Upgrade (LHD 4-8)
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: LHD 1 Class HYDRA modernization replaces the out of production P7100/MRK fixed and portable radios with XG-75 radios, replaces obsolete AN/SRC-55 (HYDRA) electronic components, adds vital wireless encrypted communications capability in below deck spaces, and incorporates the industry standard Association of Public Safety Communications Officials (APCO) P-25 signaling protocol. The HYDRA Wireless Communication System provides wireless communications capability supporting Flight Deck, Small Boat operations, Damage Control, and Security efforts. HYDRA modernization will create commonality with equipment installed in the LSD 41/49 class, CG-47 class, and CVN-68 class, as well as new construction including LHA-7, LPD-28, CVN-79 and follow-on hulls.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Funds provide for the procurement and installation of equipment in support of LCC 19/20 Class Extended Service Life Program (ESLP) extending the service life of both platforms to 2039 service life (70 year service life). Prior years include LCC electrical improvements, including new switchboards and brushless Ship Service Turbine Generators (SSTGs), VS-50+ oil water separator for environmental protection, and a qualified propulsion shaft.

FY 2018 funding request reflect a reduction of $3.171 million to account for the availability of prior year funds.
POLLUTION CONTROL SYSTEMS/EQUIPMENT: This item provides funds for the procurement of pollution control systems and equipment that are required by Navy ships in order for them to comply with international regulations, federal laws, DOD Directives and Navy environmental protection regulations. These regulations, laws and directives restrict the discharge of oily waste, sewage, solid waste, plastic waste, medical waste and hazardous waste. Most of these applicable regulations require Navy ships to comply by fixed deadlines. Failure to comply carries potential personal, civil, and criminal liability, and significantly imposes constraints on the operational capabilities of Navy ships. In some instances, the compliance schedule has required an acceleration of the normal schedules in the procurement process.
SHORE BASED POLLUTION EQUIPMENT - (Logistics) The shore based funds provide for equipment required to clean up Navy oil spills on the open sea as required by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act - Public Law 92-500. The law created a National Oil and Hazardous Substance Pollution Contingency Plan, and designates the Department of Defense as one of the primary agencies responsible for promotion of effective operation of the plan. The Supervisor of Salvage is assigned the responsibility to provide technical expertise, resources, and equipment for cleaning Navy-originated spills of oil and other hazardous material in coastal waters or the open sea. Major items of procurement are:
[P40A / HF040 FIELD SUPPORT SYSTEMS]: These systems provide the auxiliary support required to keep Navy oil spill responders operating in the field without significant lapse of response time in all Navy Areas of Responsibility (AoR) according to Federal Law 33 CFR 155 and 154 and implemented by OPNAV5090.1D. As such, many Navy areas of operation are in remote and austere parts of the world with little to no operational support available, therefore the inventory objectives of equipment procured under this cost code are set to support emergency personnel in responding to the Navy's worst case oil or hazardous substance (OHS) discharge scenario in all AoR's and to be pre-positioned in the Emergency Ship Salvage Material (ESSM) Bases world-wide. Systems include Boom Handling Boats, Boom Tending Boats, Personnel Transfer Boats, Field Command & Control Centers, Field Conference Centers, Field Rigging Lockers, Field Repair Workshops, Personnel Berthing Modules, Field-grade Satellite Communications Systems, and Oil Spill Aerial Surveillance Systems. Unit cost varies greatly between systems.
[P40A / HF051 OIL BOOM SYSTEMS]: These systems consist of inflatable or foam-filled oil booms of various sizes (18 inch, 26 inch, 42 inch). Inventory is based on the Federal requirements for Oil Spill Response Organizations (OSROs). Boom systems range in unit cost based on size (18 inch, 26 inch, 42 inch) and type (inflatable or non-inflatable). These systems include all associated equipment required to store, inflate, deploy, recover, and repair the boom, including lighting systems to mark the boom in navigable waterways. All inflatable boom systems also include shoreline transition booms to seal across beach areas. These systems are packaged in 8 foot x 8 foot x 20 foot standard shipping containers.
[P40A / HF055 SALVAGE SUPPORT SYSTEMS]: These systems are a collection of small, special-purpose oil skimmers, containment booms, shoreline transition booms, transfer pumps, temporary oil storage, sorbents, and ancillary equipment intended as a stand-alone response package for small, salvage-related spills inside and adjacent to ships in distress or inland (river and lake) spills. These systems are packaged in an 8 foot x 8 foot x 20 foot standard shipping container.
[P40A / HF056 EQUIPMENT CLEAN-UP SYSTEMS]: These systems provide a full array of tools and materials required to perform the extensive decontamination needed for oil spill and hazardous chemical response equipment and personnel during an operation and prior to demobilization once a spill has been contained and recovered.
[P40A / HF057 OIL HANDLING SYSTEMS]: Oil handling systems provide the capability to recover and dispose of oil and debris during emergency oil spill response operations including temporary oil storage as required by 33 CFR 155 and 154. Equipment missions additionally include moving heavy oil or oil in cold conditions that exceed the capability of conventional skimmer systems and providing means of transferring oil from skimmers to temporary oil storage. Systems include Vacuum Pump Systems, Oil Bladder Transfer Systems, Annular Water Injection Systems, At-Sea Bladder Pumping Systems, and Temporary Oil Storage Systems (Bladders, Tanks, etc.)These different systems can range greatly in individual unit cost.
[P40A / HF062 LIGHTERING SYSTEMS]: These systems are specially designed for lightering oil from aboard ships in distress whose transfer systems are inoperative or inaccessible or for extracting oil from sunken vessels where drilling and pumping through the hull of the vessel is often necessary at depths up to 20,000 feet. Various pump sizes and types as well as extraction tools are packaged together in fly-away systems meant to pump oil product in almost any emergency scenario. These systems are packaged in 8 foot x 8 foot x 20 foot standard shipping containers.
[P40A / HF063 VESSEL OF OPPORTUNITY SKIMMER SYSTEMS]: The Vessel of Opportunity Skimmer Systems are oil skimmers designed and packaged to be deployed aboard any vessel that is available during an emergency oil spill response operation with enough deck space to support the operating equipment. These systems allow for mechanical recovery of oil on the water in situations where traditional skimmers may not be practical, such as far offshore or in inclement weather or high currents. These systems include all the ancillary support equipment required to maintain oil spill recovery operations onboard a vessel for an extended period of time. These systems are packaged in an 8 foot x 8 foot x 20 foot standard shipping container with an 8 foot x 8 foot x 8 foot support container.
[P40A / HF067 VESSEL SKIMMER SYSTEMS]: These systems are self-propelled skimmers designed for near-shore and low sea-state open ocean environments and are used in conjunction with oil containment boom for mechanical recovery of oil on the water. They are designed to be rapidly transportable to the scene of an oil spill.
[P40A / HF031 POLLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT FIELD CHANGES]: HF031 - POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT FIELD CHANGES - Funds field changes for reliability and maintainability improvements and corrections of conventional pollution control equipment systems.
Oil Pollution Abatement (OPA) Systems Improvements: Existing OPA systems have demonstrated poor operational availability, maintainability, and reliability. This comprehensive effort addresses the entire OPA system, from holding tanks to overboard discharge, leveraging recommended improvements new to the Fleet and approved, partially completed alterations. The alterations needed to correct design deficiencies are ship specific and require ship checks to confirm the current configuration as prior alterations may have completed one or several of the recommended improvements. The alterations may include, but are not limited to: installation of new tank level sensors; upgrades to the Oily Water Separator (OWS) and the Oil Content Monitor (OCM), correction of OWS suction problems, correction of OCM inlet & outlet piping including related of flush water piping configuration problems, and upgrade of oily waste transfer pump relief valve. Extensive work will occur with LHD-1 Class upgrades to convert the existing OWS to the VS-50 OWS and DDG-51 through DDG-88 ships will receive the Oily Waste Membrane System to produce an effluent that meets the 15 ppm maximum oil discharge requirement.
[P40A / HF830 PRODUCTION ENGINEERING]: HF830 PRODUCTION ENGINEERING: Air conditioning plant kit and software quality control, technical manual and complete conversion instruction revisions, technical reports based on investigative efforts of OEM quality assurance or obsolescence issues, and support equipment removal from inactive ships or other Navy assets. Development of technical manuals, Planned Maintenance System (PMS), Provisioning Technical Documentation (PTD), Program Support Data (PSD) and allowance Parts List (APLs), engineering to manage procurement and material, and in support of design reviews.
[P3A / HF024 CFC-114 (R-114) AC CONVERSION]: HF024 - CFC CONVERSION PROGRAM The production of chlorofluorocarbon(CFC)-based refrigerants (including CFC-12 and CFC R-114) was prohibited after 31 DEC 95 by the Clean Air Act of 1990. Presidential Executive Order 13693 calls for federal agencies to " promote sustainable acquisition and procurement by ensuring that each of the following environmental performance and sustainability factors are included ... alternatives to ozone-depleting substances". The Navy is currently dependent on CFC-based refrigerants for the mission-critical cooling of (1) vital electronics and weapon systems, (2) food and medical stowage, and (3) inhabited spaces aboard surface ships and submarines. To counter the immediate threat of production cessation on uninterrupted Fleet operations, DoD directed the Defense Logistics Agency to establish a stockpile of CFC-based refrigerants. The stockpile was sized to support Fleet operations until the last CFC-based systems are retired or converted to ozone-friendly refrigerants. This program procures and installs conversion kits on existing CFC R-114 Air-Conditioning (A/C) plants onboard surface ships. The CFC R-114 conversion program began in FY 99 and is expected to complete FY2021. The inventory objective for CFC R-114 is 402 converted units.
[P3A / HF024 CFC-114 (R-114) AC CONVERSION]: HF5IN - INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT Funding is for installation of equipment for the Fleet Modernization Program installations.
HF6IN - INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT Funding is for installation of equipment for the Fleet Modernization Program installations.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification: FY 2018 funding request reflect a reduction of $3.171 million to account for the availability of prior year funds.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Submarine Support Equipment budget provides for equipment technical refresh and upgrades that consist of hardware, software, system engineering, integrated logistics support, system test and evaluation, training, data, installation assistance teams and program management. This funding also procures equipment and material used to implement the military high priority Submarine Silencing Program for operating nuclear submarines. This equipment technical refreshes and upgrades are not supported by other NAVSEA program offices and support SSN/SSBN/SSGN Class submarines and land based laboratories/facilities.
The installation funds are provided for the Ship Service Turbine Generator (SSTG) Governors on SSN688 and SSN21 Class submarines, acoustic range array replacement, Ship Control System Processors for Seawolf Class submarines, and SSN Class Component Upgrades.
[P40A / Fwd Automatic Bus Transfer Pwr Mod]: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - Forward Automatic Bus Transfer (ABT) Power Modification - The in-service VA ships in Block I/II have received the Hotel Services SHIPALT which included Static ABTs and power transformers to support increased forward electronics processing capability for continuing SWFTS sonar/fire control tech insertions. At-sea operations have since identified problems with loss of electronics processing in conjunction with a loss of power to a forward electrical bus. A new construction change for blocks III/IV platforms is in progress, but a backfit SHIPALT for a power distribution upgrade on blocks I/II must be developed and fielded on SSN 774-783. Material lead time is estimated to be less than 12 months.
[P40A / MRO Shock Mod SA 4629K]: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - Manual Remote Operator (MRO) Shock Modification (SHIPALT 4620K) - Accomplishes design changes on 20 MROs per ship to meet shock qualification requirement. The MROs are for valves AHP-33, TD-138, DSW-1, DSW-2, TD-128, TD-65, TD-129, SDA-8I, PL-2, SDA-82, TD-127, TD-49, SDA-53, SDA-54, SDA-41, TD-125, PL-81, EAFW-244, EAFW-245 and EAFW-67. Backfit installation of the SHIPALT is planned for SSN 774-781 (782 - 783 received at PSA).
[P40A / Circuit Cathodic Protection Sys OER]: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - CKT D / Cathodic Protection System Obsolete Equipment Replacement (OER): Circuit D supports degaussing operations. The current design on block I/II ships is 1990's COTS and is obsolete, requiring tech refresh to block III design via a backfit SHIPALT design and fielding. Additionally, future upgrade of the VA Class SWFTS sonar/fire control systems to TI-16/APB-15 or greater involve a change of middleware from CORBA to AMPQ, requiring CKT D to also transition to AMPQ. This transition requires a CKT D redesign and upgrade by SHIPALT. The cathodic protection system on VA Class blocks I/II ships uses an Impressed Current Cathodic Protection electronics that is COTS-based. Due to continued obsolescence with in-service ships, a complete system redesign is planned in new construction block V that would require backfit on in-service ships to allow the ICCP system to continue providing hull structure corrosion protection and maintain interfaces with other systems like CKT D. The redesign effort for the two systems will result in separate SHIPALTS but are related due to system interfaces. Block I/II platforms (SSN 774-783) require upgrade. Change applicability to Block III platforms is under review.
[P40A / SSTG Reliability Upgrades]: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - Ships Service Turbine Generator (SSTG) Reliability Upgrades - Recent failures on in-service VA Class submarines of the SSTG bearing system design have identified the need for both short term and longer term corrective design actions. SHIPALT design development is required for several system improvements including modifications to the Bearing Thrust Housing Chamfer to increase air flow and reduce temperatures, the Bearing Thrust Moisture Sensor to seal sensor internals from moisture and reduce introduction of moisture to the thrust housing, and installation of a Flow Diverter to seal existing gaps between gland seals on the turbine and the forward end of the thrust bearing. Longer term corrective action for block I/II ships (SSN 774-783) involves redesign and possible replacement of bearing system, depending on results of ongoing failure analysis. Impact to Block III platforms is to be determined.
[P40A / VA Class Acoustic Superiority Prog Acoustic Superior]: PB002 SSN Component Upgrades - VA Class Acoustic Superiority - Design Development - Funding will be utilized to execute requirements included in "PEO SUBMARINES ASW CAMPAIGN PLAN UPDATE, 9073 Ser 450W4K/S0116 of 2 Mar 2016". This letter (SECRET) provides details on the plan to backfit new design AS treatment on 5 BLK III submarines during their first EDSRA, with follow-on installs on 6 BLK IV submarines during their EDSRAs. In addition, design work for backfit SHIPALT development for selected machinery improvements is included. AS treatment installations will be based on design and material developed for installation on USS SOUTH DAKOTA (SSN 790) as part of the South Dakota Improvement Program (SDIP) during PSA. Beginning in FY18, funding is provided for development of SHIPALT products for backfit installation of the AS treatment by Naval Shipyards on VA Class hulls, as well as for SHIPALT development for backfit of AS-related machinery improvements by EDSRA Shipyards or Fleet IMAs. Funding is also provided for design and beginning in FY20 for fabrication of staging enclosures for use by the EDSRA shipyards and for handling and application equipment required for AS treatment installations. Engineering services are also funded to provide processes and procedures to the EDSRA shipyards for handling, setup and operation of staging enclosures and for the treatment handling and application equipment.
[P40A / Acoustic Range Replacement Equipment]: PB004 Facilities/Lab Upgrades - Procures equipment and materials required to implement and support the military high priority Submarine Silencing Program for operating nuclear submarines. TYCOMs have consistently rated the conduct of noise trials as a high priority funding requirement. The requirements for this program are identified in Chief of Naval Operations (CNO) Specific Operational Requirements 46-28 and Naval Sea Systems Instruction (NAVSEAINST) C9073.2B. This is the only program in place to procure equipment for the purpose of measuring, monitoring, assessing and improving the detection capability and reducing the detectability of deployed submarines. The equipment is used on test vessels, listening platforms and at the laboratories. This program replaces or refurbishes broken or obsolete acquisition and analysis hardware and software used to ensure ship's safety; and the execution and completion of acoustic trials objectives identified in CNO SOR 46-28 (assessment of ship's acoustic posture, etc.) and NAVSEAINST C9073.2B (Acoustic Surveys Policy). These refurbishments and replacements are especially critical in order to maintain the technological advances recently made in the area of acoustic data acquisition under the Acoustic Measurement Facilities Improvement Program and to utilize the South Tongue of the Ocean Acoustic Facility (STAFAC). Specific items include hydrophone arrays, towed arrays, ranging and tracking systems, on-board array electronics, noise sources, shore power cables, data fiber optic cables, data analysis systems, workstations, data storage and retrieval, communications systems, analyzers, tape recorders, accelerometers, monitors, etc.
[P40A / SW Class SC Proc Design & Dev]: PB007 SSN HM&E Threshold Modernization - Provides for replacement of Seawolf Class Ship Control System Microprocessing unit. The current Ship Control System microprocessors are obsolete and contain electronic components that are no longer support by industry.
[P40A / LA/SW Class Design and Shipalt Dev. for SSTG Governors]: PB008 SSTG Governors - Provides for replacement of submarine Ship Service Turbine Generator (SSTG) Governors on Seawolf Class and Los Angeles Class (MOD 25). The SSTG Governors in these submarines classes are obsolete and contain electronic components that are no longer supported by industry.

proc:Name.footnote: Totals shown for SSN Class Component Upgrades (PB002), SEAWOLF Class HM&E Threshold Modernization (PB007) and SSTG Governors (PB008) are for SHIPALT design documentation and Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) product preparation costs. Procurement quantities and installation costs for these items are shown on the P-3a exhibits. Facilities/Lab Upgrades (PB004) procures equipment and materials required to implement and support the high priority Submarine Silencing Program for operating Strategic and Attack nuclear submarines.

In FY18, two procurements are started with one procurement and three installations to follow. The FY16 Design funding is completion of residual design effort for the SEAWOLF Class SSTG governor.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: PB002 Propulsor Upgrade

proc:Name.footnote: VA Class Modernization is planned for installation during depot availabilities (EDSRA or DMP) of approx. 20 Months duration.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - Propulsor Upgrade SHIPALT 4548K - Current propulsor design on VA class in-service ships exhibits excessive corrosion problems. A SHIPALT has been developed to accomplish modifications to the propulsor, shaft, bearing snubber, forward outer structure cover plate, rotor tailcone, rope guard, fastener system, and associated local cathodic protection system, to achieve a 156 month corrosion protection system for the propulsor without interim repairs or replacement. Backfit installation was initially started by the VA Class program office and has transitioned to PMS392 to procure the remaining three ships of the five shipsets and install the remaining five shipsets.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: PB002 SSTG Digital Voltage

proc:Name.footnote: VA Class Modernization is planned for installation during depot availabilities (EDSRA or DMP) of approx. 20 Months duration.

proc:Item.proc:Name: SSTG Digital Voltage Requlator SA 4884K -- Procurement
SSTG Digital Voltage Requlator SA 4884K -- Installation

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - Ships Service Turbine Generator (SSTG) Digital Voltage Regulator upgrade (SHIPALT 4884K) - Existing SSTGs on early VA Class submarines have analog voltage regulators, which are obsolete and unsustainable. SSN 780 and later ships were delivered with the new design Digital Voltage Regulator. A backfit SHIPALT has been developed to replace the analog voltage regulators on SSN 774-779 with the new digital design, targeted to begin in FY18. This effort began under budget line item 0942 and has transitioned to 0941 beginning in FY18 where the remaining five of six shipsets will be procured and all six shipsets will be installed.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: PB002 ICS Design Change

proc:Name.footnote: VA Class Modernization is planned for installation during depot availabilities (EDSRA or DMP) of approx. 20 Months duration.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks: PB002 SSN Class Component Upgrades - Integrated Communications System (ICS) - The interior Integrated Communication System installation on VA Class ships Block I/II hulls is a COTS based system designed in the mid-1990s and first installed in 2002. Much of the design is now obsolete and unsupported. The ICS must be operational to meet underway requirements. Back-fitting the Block I/II platforms with the updated Block III system avoids a complete redesign, but there are parts of the updated Block III design that are projected to become obsolete in the future. The block III design is currently being evaluated for possible additional updates to processor cards, graphics cards, Asynchronous Transfer Mode switches, Linear Displacement Transducers, Absolute Pressure Transducers and touchscreen displays to resolve near term projected obsolescence, with development of a backfit SHIPALT in FY17 for fielding in FY 18 -FY22 on eight ships by PMS392. This effort began in line item 0942 and transitioned to 0941 in FY18 where the remaining seven shipsets will be procured and eight shipsets will be installed.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The VIRGINIA Class BLI 0942 provides a wide range of material required to operate, test, support and maintain the viability of VIRGINIA SSN-774 Class Submarines. The "Major Shore Spares" component includes rotatable pool and insurance spares. Propulsor rotatable pool assets support planned maintenance during scheduled availabilities by decreasing equipment turn-around time/availability duration. Rotatable pool program equipment includes the high pressure air compressor, various pump/motor assemblies, radar mast, ventilation fans and thin line towed array components and other components. There is a significant increase in the profile of this component from FY18 through FY20 in support of additional high speed machining capabilities at the Naval Foundry and Propeller Center (NFPC) in Philadelphia. This is the VIRGINIA Program Office portion of the propulsor foundry equipment as agreed to by PEO SUB, VIRGINIA Program Office, and ORP Program Office.
This funding line also includes upgrading the afloat acoustic system required to conduct TECHEVAL/OPEVAL satisfactorily, efficiently and with minimal risk of equipment failure. Conduct hardware and software development, procurement, maintenance, and operations as required to achieve and maintain submarine acoustic signatures trials program. The resultant capabilities support the Submarine Acoustic Trials Enterprise, which includes the VIRGINIA Class submarine test and evaluation program. Also included in the Vertical Launch System (VLS) Peculiar Support Equipment (PSE) are primarily All-Up Round Simulators (AURS)/All-Up Round (AUR) Ballast Cans necessary to conduct TECHEVAL/OPEVAL and provide ballast for ship operation.
The wireless LAN provides a ship wide (forward of the reactor compartment) intranet (Non-classified Internet Protocol (IP) Router Network (Unclassified Enclave) (NIPRNET)) that significantly enhances the quality of the work by facilitating electronic correspondence, personnel data management, collaborative services, interactive whiteboard, multi-user chat and access to these sites: Fleet Training Management & Planning System/Navy Training Management & Planning System (FTMPS/NTMPS), Composite Health Care System (CHCS), prescriptions, MYPAY-Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS), Navy Personnel Command (NPC), Bureau of Naval Personnel (BUPERS), email, Fleet Technical Support Center, Atlantic (FTSCLANT), Submarine Maintenance Engineering, Planning and Procurement (SUBMEPP) and Navy Knowledge Online (NKO).
Maintenance Planning System funds will be used to help ship programs identify, plan and execute maintenance activities as well as improve efficiently at all levels (performed by ship's force as well as organizational/depot level) by creating a set of tools to provide a robust, disconnected and comprehensive training and maintenance solution delivering dynamic content. This set of tools and the associated ship-to-shore data environment will reduce O&MN funding over time. This will be fielded as part of the Non-Tactical Data Processing System (NTDPS) to VIRGINIA Class submarines.
Additionally, the continuous ship upgrades necessary to maintain class viability of the earlier ships are included in this funding line. This is particularly important for Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS) Technology Refreshment and Technology Upgrades for Non-Propulsion Electronic Systems (NPES). The class level of modernization and capability rests on available resources.

proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Name: HRC13 - Hotel Services
proc:P40AItemGroup.proc:Remarks:
Models of Systems Affected: VA Class Submarines Type Modification: Various
Provide procurement of materials necessary to modernize VIRGINIA Class Submarine Blocks I & II (774-783) infrastructure (i.e. power, cabling, cooling, and arrangements of the ship for the entire Government Furnished Equipment (GFE)/ Contractor Furnished Equipment (CFE) NPES configuration). This combination of Hull, Mechanical and Electrical (HM&E) alterations to VIRGINIA Class submarines is collectively referred to as the "Hotel Services" modification. This Hotel Service modification is necessary to accommodate modernization to major combat system alterations (i.e. A-RCI, AN/BYG-1, and ISIS) and are completed concurrently with those major combat system alterations. TI-02 baseline systems Hotel Services modernizations are completed during Post Shakedown Availability (PSA) for SSN777 and SSN779-783 and during EDSRA or TYCOM Operational Availability (TOA) for SSN774-SSN776 and SSN778. Block III and follow ships do not require this significant HM&E infrastructure upgrade as the baseline design for those ships accounts for the necessary power, cabling, cooling, etc. required to host upgrades to major combat systems.
Hotel Services modernization kit procurement for SSN778 takes place in FY16 and is installed during FY17 EDSRA. Kit procurement for SSN774 takes place in FY18 and is installed during FY19 DMP.
Note: Actual costs associated with the HSWG installation on SSN 775 during EDSRA (FY12-13) have necessitated the Department to increase planned installation budget on current and future installations (Budgeted: FY17-778 and Planned FY19-774).

Provide procurement of materials necessary to modernize VIRGINIA Class unique Contractor Furnished Equipment (CFE) to sustain interfaces and technology baseline with the connecting Government Furnished sub-systems contained in the Non-Propulsion Electronics System suite. These sub-systems include; Portable Ship Control System (PSCS), Total Ship Monitoring System, Circuit D, Ship Control System, Light Weight Wide Aperture Array and Interior Communication System.

Procure and install obsolescence redesign for Ship Control System (SCS) on Block I and II. The material procurement in FY14-17 includes long lead items for four shipsets for backfit (SSN776-SSN779).

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This funding procures long-lead major end items required for repairs to both variants of Littoral Combat Ships (LCS). The items procured mitigate major long-lead replacement times due to unplanned system failures and casualties and increases availability of vital Fleet assets by reducing repair part procurement and delivery times. Funding procures support equipment, required ancillary equipment, and associated engineering and technical support services for LCS.
LN001 - LCS Battle Spares This line procures shore-based battle spares, ensuring their availability in the event of a failure or major casualty to key systems. Systems that require shore-based spares include gas turbines, diesel engines and generators, propulsion systems, reduction gears, auxiliary propulsion units (APUs), and machinery plant control & monitoring systems (MPCMSs). Inventory objectives are determined by the LCS Reliability, Maintainability, and Availability (RMA) Plan, NAVSEA RMA guidance, the critical application of equipment, and vendor data.
LN002 - LCS Water Jet Spares Both LCS variants are propelled by water jets; this line procures spare water jets and water jet components. There are two LCS designs, the FREEDOM variant and the INDEPENDENCE variant, each using four water jets. The FREEDOM variant uses Rolls-Royce water jets and the INDEPENDENCE variant uses Wartsila Lips water jets. The water jet assemblies are mounted externally on the ships' transom. These items will be designated 2S cog material and support a rotable pool for life cycle sustainment. In the event of a casualty, the water jets are removed and sent to a depot to be repaired.
LN003 - Engineering Services This funding provides engineering and technical support for LCS Class Support Equipment. Services include the establishment of Technical Data Packages (TDPs) and the creation of associated depot level repair parts lists/installation requirements. Funding is also provided for Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) and Design Services Allocation (DSA) modernization efforts tied to the ship availabilities.
LN004 - Habitability Modification In FY16, the budget funded Habitability Modifications (berthing racks and potable water) to increase permanent berthing to 98 for FREEDOM and INDEPENDENCE variants for LCS 5 thru LCS 8. FY17 budget funds berthing spaces, refrigeration (chill and freeze), dry provision stores, potable water, solid waste storage, and laundry.
LN005 - LCS Ships Class Safety Design Changes Safety modifications include the redesigned stern ramp for the FREEDOM variant ships to support 11M Rigid Hull Inflatable Boats (RHIB) operations and the installation of bridge wing for safe and effective operation on the INDEPENDENCE variant ships. In FY18, the budget for the LCS Ships Class Safety Design Changes was realigned to LI 1604, LCS In-Service Modernization.
LN006 - LCS Ships Class Ancillary Equipment This funding procures the connective equipment necessary to ensure fit and function of procured LCS Class Support Equipment when installed.
LN007 - AFSB SOF MODs This funding procures the 3-D Air Search Radar to modify the Mobile Landing Platform-Afloat Forward Staging Base (MLP-AFSB) (Expeditionary Mobile Base, ESB) to support Special Operations Forces (SOF) requirements.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
LN001 - LCS Battle Spares This line procures shore-based battle spares to ensure their availability in the event of a failure or major casualty to key systems. FY18 procure 2 MT-30 Gas Turbine Engine procurement (Inclusive of all sub assemblies), as opposed to the procurement of individual/fully-usable sub-assemblies (stages) in previous years. Additionally Radars for both Variants are being procured along with Main Propulsion Diesel Engines (MPDE) for both variants.
LN002 - LCS Water Jet Spares LCS water jets procurements in the event of a casualty, none procured in FY18.
LN003 - Engineering Services This funding provides engineering and technical support for LCS Class Support Equipment develops Technical Data Packages (TDPs) and creates associated depot level repair parts lists/installation requirements.
LN004 - Habitability Modification Habitability Modifications (racks, increased provisioning stowage, solid waste stowage, laundry capacity and potable water) to increase permanent berthing to 98 for FREEDOM and INDEPENDENCE variants.
LN005 - LCS Ships Class Safety Design Changes Safety modifications include the redesigned stern ramp for the FREEDOM variant ships to support 11M Rigid Hull Inflatable Boats (RHIB) operations and the installation of bridge wing for safe and effective operation on the INDEPENDENCE variant ships.
LN006 - LCS Ships Class Ancillary Equipment This funding procures the connective equipment necessary to ensure fit and function of procured Class Support Equipment when installed.
LN007 - AFSB SOF MODs This funding procures the 3-D Air Search Radar to modify the Mobile Landing Platform-Afloat Forward Staging Base (MLP-AFSB) (Expeditionary Mobile Base, ESB) to support Special Operations Forces (SOF) requirements.
